It seems to me like 'mctp' should probably become a machine feature of some sort rather than an "-extra".  It isn't just some random debug tool...
libmctp is our "real" stuff, https://grok.openbmc.org/xref/openbmc/openbmc/meta-openembedded/meta-networking/recipes-support/mctp/mctp_git.bb?r=2194f503 does seem to just be a utility recipe.

It's the tooling for configuring kernel mctp. It's equivalent to the `ip` tools and a dhcp server, and is required if you want to do mctp in openbmc going forward. libmctp for use in openbmc is effectively deprecated.

> is required if you want to do mctp in openbmc going forward

Right.  That was my assumption as well.  This is why I suggested we put this as a FEATURE of some sort (machine, distro, image?) in meta-phosphor rather than burying it in an "-extras" on all the various meta-layers that happen to be using MCTP today.
I agree
Done

Hi Patrick,

I'm not sure if this is the best way to add mctp to DISTRO_FEATURES and use it. What are your thoughts?
Like the overall direction.  Have a few nits.
Suggest keeping these sorted rather than appending.

This tpm one is wrong and I've been reminded to fix it in the background...

For your mctp one you also need to add the .cfg file to the SRC_URI.
Done
Done
Isn't MCTP support a machine feature and not a distro feature?
Ack
I'd argue that MCTP is a distro feature as we may want to support MCTP devices that aren't necessarily dictated by the platform design (customer choice NVMe drives supporting NVMe-MI for example).

A separate thought here is that none of the kernel config is Aspeed-specific, so we can move the `.scc` and `.cfg` files into `meta-phosphor` instead. This allows the feature to be used on Nuvoton an HPE GXP SoCs also, without any further work required.
Done
I'm good, may want to check with Joel as the meta-aspeed maintainer to ensure he's good here too.

I'm not sure that MACHINE_FEATURES is best here. Really the only common bit of MCTP infra that all MCTP-supporting systems will use is CONFIG_MCTP. Some will then enable one of the device drivers, such as MCTP_SERIAL or MCTP_TRANSPORT_I2C. And then some will want to enable the TAP interface to perform injection from userspace, but others won't.

We could solve this by

 1. enabling all of the options.
 
 2. have each board enable the options it requires.

I would vote for 2.

Or we can define a new variable for the various transports we want enabled.  I don't think that settings us up to have to maintain N different kernel config snippets is a great idea considering many systems are likely to have similar needs and this gives us a centralized place to update Kconfig values as-needed.

The TAP interface is going to be a requirement of PLDM, isn't it?  Almost everyone is moving in the direction of needing PLDM.  (I'm supposing this based on conversation AndrewJ and Jeremy were having on Discord).

I think MACHINE_FEATURES is overkill for this.

fwiw I would vote that by default, OpenBMC "just works" and you need to do as little as possible to configure it.  So turning on all the kernel config options by default, and enabling all the pmci applications by default.  Anyone that wants to optimize for space, or any other reason, can do so in their board configuration.

You can even share these sets of optimizations through other, new layers - in yocto that's called distro policy.

Here's what Meta are doing to enable MCTP:

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/62827

Do we want all the platforms copying that? Probably not. So I think either we want a machine feature or to do what Meta have done in meta-phosphor instead.

>  So turning on all the kernel config options by default, and enabling all the pmci applications by default. Anyone that wants to optimize for space, or any other reason, can do so in their board configuration.

Wouldn't that be easiest to achieve with a `DISTRO_FEATURE` switch in the broad sense? "I don't want to support MCTP therefore I want all of that turned off." Fine-tuning beyond that ("I need MCTP enabled but I know my platform doesn't require the PCIe VDM MCTP transport binding") is something that seems reasonable to deal with under the metadata for a specific platform.
Done
I assume no conflict with our current userspace mctp and this new in-kernel mctp being enabled in the same flash image?

Not with this patch. The only conflict arises between the mctp-demux.service and the one that uses the in-kernel mctp, as they both use the libmctp astlpc binding. As long as we remove or disable mctp-demux.service when we add in that new service, we should be fine.
Is this part for backwards compatibility?  I'm just trying to understand for my own benefit.

We require a vendor-defined MCTP transport binding that's currently implemented in libmctp: the ASTLPC binding. We don't yet have an in-kernel implementation for it, so we're using TUN to continue to exploit the userspace implementation until we can do the kernel implementation. This approach allows us to do the rest of the foundational work to transition the OpenBMC userspace away from libmctp to `AF_MCTP` sockets.

Put another way, `CONFIG_TUN=y` isn't something that's generally required for use of `AF_MCTP` sockets. It's specific to how IBM is approaching the integration work, for now.
Done
I wonder whether we should do the `DISTRO_FEATURES += " mctp"` in `meta-phosphor` instead of `meta-ibm`, but otherwise this looks good.
Before I merge this I'll probably take this commit and the meta-facebook one and try to ensure they are common and as reusable as possible.  Some refactoring might happen.
Is PLDM part of PMCI?  Should we put the PLDM daemon into here or should we be defining a new pldm DISTRO_FEATURE also?
I think that would be a good idea.

Sorry, that was a vague and therefore meaningless response. I think I was responding to the idea of adding the `pldm` package to the `dmtf-pmci` package group. But on reflection I think aiming for a `dmtf-pmci` package group is overly broad for now, and maybe we should just tack the `mctp` package onto an existing package group based on the presence of the `mctp` `DISTRO_FEATURE`.

Thoughts?

Having looked through the other groups we define here it's unclear which one would be most appropriate for the `mctp` package. Maybe we just leave the `dmtf-pmci` group as is for now with just the `mctp` package? We can revisit whether or not we include `pldm` in that package group later?
Done
This is really not obvious.  Please us bb.utils.contains even though the 'mctp' feature and the 'mctp' desired-package are the same.
Hah! I thought it was neat. Seems it was too neat.
Done

Looking at [2.12 Adding Recipe-Space Kernel Features][1] I think this means we also need the following?

```
KERNEL_FEATURES:append = " ${@bb.utils.contains('DISTRO_FEATURES', 'mctp', 'mctp.scc', '', d)}"
```

[1]: https://docs.yoctoproject.org/current/singleindex.html#adding-recipe-space-kernel-features

I don't think we need `KERNEL_FEATURES` as `mctp.scc` is conditionally added to `SRC_URI` based on `DISTRO_FEATURES`. When I remove `mctp` from `DISTRO_FEATURES` I see `CONFIG MCTP is not set` in the config file.
Ack. Thanks for clearing up my brain-fade.
Should be fine to land as soon as CI passed.
